awd_titl_txt: Novel Spontaneous Four-wave Mixing Techniques for Photon-pair Generation and Hyperentanglement
awd_abstract_narration:
Entanglement plays a crucial role in many quantum information protocols.  This project will help researchers understand and control the generation of entanglement, and hyperentanglement, using novel spontaneous four-wave mixing techniques.  The researchers' work on hyperentanglement generation in an optical fiber will also enable a new type of quantum information encoding, which is a step towards enhancing the information capacity carried on a single photon and thus allowing faster secure communication.  Their development of an efficient technique for probing hyperentanglement will enable other investigators to quickly and precisely engineer photon-pair sources  for quantum applications. This research on photon-pair generation via Raman interaction is expected to clarify the process in which the photons are created, towards the realization of a new type of photon-pair source that is better suited for quantum applications such as quantum computation, quantum communication and precision sensing.  To help inform the public about the quantum nature of light, the investigators will develop a display illustrating the concept of wave-particle duality for the University of Illinois physics building lobby and engineering open house. They will also present public outreach lectures and introduce course material that gives undergraduate students insight into the quantum properties of light. The research will also provide professional training to graduate and undergraduate students in quantum optics.

Due to the ubiquitous use of photon-pair sources in quantum research and quantum applications, there have been major efforts to develop novel sources that produce photons in specific application-required quantum states. The investigators will develop a new type of photon-pair source based on the Raman interaction in crystalline materials, wherein the emission of photons is mediated by resonant excitation of a phonon, thus affecting the photon spectral properties in a way that differentiates this process from the traditional techniques of spontaneous parametric downconversion (SPDC) or spontaneous four-wave mixing (SFWM). Specifically, the researchers expect this process to naturally reduce spectral intra-correlations within the photon-pair, as opposed to SPDC and SFWM, for which special engineering techniques must be used that often result in unsatisfactory outcomes. They anticipate the research community will find further use for the newly developed principles in other Raman systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated new approaches and platforms for the generation, control, and storage of quantum states of light. The project provided fundamental theoretical descriptions of the correlations between light and matter as well as practical guidance on optimizing light-matter interaction for quantum technologies. This work contributes to the harnessing of quantum states of light for quantum information processing, quantum sensing, and fundamental studies of quantum mechanics.

The project developed a theoretical description of the photon-matter quantum correlations that arise in spontaneous Raman scattering. It explored these correlations experimentally to compare with theory and employed the correlations to probe the phonon dephasing dynamics in thin van Der Waals materials. Spontaneous Raman scattering was further explored in an integrated waveguide platform for generation of photon pairs with controllable delay for quantum information processing.

Optical fiber was utilized as a platform for generating new types of quantum states of light and demonstrating new methods of controlling photon-pair quantum correlations and entanglement. The project demonstrated entanglement of three photons in the energy degree of freedom in a form that provides robustness to loss and suitability for fundamental tests of quantum mechanics. New methods of controlling the quantum correlations of photon pairs generated in optical fiber were developed that use two pumps at different wavelengths, enabling the creation and characterization of photon pairs in optimized states for quantum information processing. The spatial, or transverse-mode degree of freedom, was explored to generate transverse-mode-entangled photon pairs in polarization-maintaining optical fiber. Ring-core fiber was used to demonstrate a new platform for photon-pair generation and control via orbital angular momentum states.

Theoretical and experimental studies of storage and retrieval of THz- bandwidth photonic quantum states were undertaken, resulting in new tools for optimization and demonstrations of record storage efficiency in a new quantum memory platform. Theoretically, the optimization of three-level quantum memory platforms was explored under the experimentally relevant condition of Gaussian pulse shapes for the control field that implements storage and retrieval, revealing such pulse shapes are sufficient for optimization across a wide range of parameter space. Sensitivity to fluctuations and drift of memory and control field parameters was explored to provide guidance for efficiently optimizing experimental implementations. Experimentally, a quantum memory was developed in atomic barium vapor that exhibited record storage efficiencies above 95% and very low noise, enhancing the ability to store and retrieve THz-bandwidth photons on demand for quantum information applications.

The results of this project have a broader impact in the form of workforce development in quantum information. Graduate and undergraduate students were introduced into the scientific community and received training in quantum optics experiment and theory through their work on the project. A modern experimental physics course at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign was enhanced by the addition of new quantum optics experiments that provide hands-on experience in quantum optics research for undergraduate students.
